content.description:
WHY RAINCOATS ARE YELLOW 5.7 *** 90' G

Begin with the short left facing corner at the left end of the south face, and climb directly up the cracks and ledges above to the cold shuts just below the top. Excellent rock, gear (a wide range of cams and nuts needed) and climbing!
content.protection: Gear - large to small cams and nuts
content.location: the intermittent crack system at the left end of the main south face

content.description:
VENUS OF OKANOGAN 5.7 **** 90' M (9b)

Begin 5' left of the Why Raincoats Are Yellow crack and climb directly up. Pass the short lower diagonal corner on the right and climb the face above, then head left for the arete (avoiding the Raincoats route completely), 2 chain anchors (brown) are above (10' 3rd class scramble) just below the top lip. Several medium and small cams are needed throughout between the bolts. Excellent variety of climbing.
content.protection: Mixed - 9 bolts and several medium to small cam placements
content.location: face just left of the intermittent vertical cracks at the left end of the main south face.

content.description:
SE BUTTRESS RIGHT SIDE  5.4 ** 80' M/F (7b)

Begin a few feet left of  Tootie Fruity and climb directly up, traversing left to the cold shuts at the top bolt (shared with the Left Side route). Can be climbed without any gear, but a #2 cam may be needed between 4th and 5th bolts for a leader not solid at the 5.6 or higher grade.
content.protection: fixed - 7 bolts to the cold shut anchors on top (#2 cam maybe wanted between 4th and 5th bolts)

content.description:
SE BUTTRESS LEFT SIDE 5.5 ** 70' F (6b)

Begin in the big corner on the far left of the SE Buttress. After a few feet stem off the corner and head up the wall on the right to the cold shuts on top. Fun, but may seem a bit dicey with the flakey rock and is probably harder for a short climber!

SBD (Silent But Deadly)  5.6 *  85' F (8b)

Climbs the clean line up the right end of the main face, beginning in a shallow groove just left of the lower big corner (above the ledge with Oregon Grape), follow the arete to the top and traverse left to the cold shuts.  Fun steep climbing through some brittle rock down low. Overall, may seem hard for the grade.
content.location: 1st route on the right end of the main south face (just left of the short large chimney sized crack/corner)

content.description:
RETURN OF THE MIGHTY M.O.G.S 5.2 ** 80' F (6b)

Start as for A Mighty Wind, and continue up the diagonal crack to the face right of that route, to the same anchors. Sustained and fun, especially for 'men of girth'.
content.protection: fixed - 6 bolts to chain anchors on top
content.location: Far right end of Big Butte's south face

content.description:
OLD FARTS 5.5 * 90' M (5b)

The face left of the large vertical crack to the cold shuts on top.  A bouldery start 10' left of the crack leads to a series of short seams (dark flaky rock). A range of cams is needed for the easier upper face.
content.protection: mixed - 5 bolts and a wide range of cams
content.location: The face just left of the vertical crack.

content.description:
NATURAL GAS 5.3 * 90' G

The main vertical crack. Medium cams or hexes needed for top anchors at the lip
content.protection: Gear, large to medium cams and nuts. Gear anchor needed at the top.
content.location: Climb the obvious vertical crack on the right side of the main south face.

content.description:
GLUTEOUS MAX 5.8 ** 95' F (10b)

The middle of the face to the chain rap anchors, (with an extra belay anchor at cairn). Begin just right of the obvious crack  watch out for poison ivy in the crack and on the first ledge - (10' left of OLD FARTS), cross left at first bolt and continue directly up.
content.location: middle of the face starting at the short vertical crack (with poison ivy in it)

content.description:
BUTTE-EOUS MAXIMUS  5.7 ** 95' M (5b)

The steeper left side of the main south face, directly below the cold shuts on top. Begin 10' right of the "Why Raincoats Are Yellow" crack and climb the dark lower bulge (crux mantle on flaky rock), to the big ledge and delightful upper face. A range of cams is needed for the easier upper face. Consistent climbing on mostly wonderful rock.
content.protection: mixed, 5 bolts and range of cams
content.location: the face just right of the intermittent vertical cracks at the left side of the main south face.

content.description:
BREAK LIKE THE WIND   5.4 ** 90' M (5b)

Begin at the thin jagged gear protected crack just right of the prominent vertical crack, and climb the face to the cold shuts on top. Upper third is gear protected in pockets (range of medium cams/tricams needed, as well as a small nut before the first bolt). Fun!
content.protection: mixed - 5 bolts and a variety of cams/nuts
content.location: The face just right of the obvious vertical crack on the right side of the main south face

content.description:
TOOTIE FRUITY 5.4 ** 75' F (6b)

Sustained and surprisingly fun climbing up the face directly below the chain anchors. About 25' left of A Mighty Wind, begin up the edge of the broken arete left of the alcove. May seem hard for the grade, especially for a shorter climber.
content.protection: fixed - 6 bolts, although some gear also possible

content.description:
A MIGHTY WIND 5.3 *** 75' F (7b)

From the lowest point on the buttress (right of the alcove with the Service Berry and Poison Ivy) begin at the diagonal crack and climb up and slightly left to the 2 short chain anchors over the top. This and Tootie Fruity would make for a great practice gear lead (a range of cams can be placed near the bolts), with sustained very nice climbing on mostly excellent, clean rock.
content.protection: fixed - 7 bolts (although some gear is possible)
